Department of Chemistry Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur 208016 India Graphical abstract The exceptional attributes of porous organic polymers (POPs) such as high physicochemical stability, intrinsic microporosity, and customised access from simple organic building blocks render them highly suitable as catalytic nanosized reactors. These materials can be engineered in a ‘bottom-up’ fashion by integrating catalytic components into the polymeric structures through facile synthesis based on rationally designed building blocks and judicious selection of the polymerization reactions. Herein, we report that a POP adorned by free carboxylic acid functionalities (Carboxy-POP) on its surface works remarkably as a heterogeneous catalyst for metal-free transamidation, a fundamentally important transformation, of diverse unactivated carboxamides and thiocarboxamides with aliphatic, aromatic and cyclic amines. The protocol is also shown to be applicable for the transimidation of challenging substrates such as phthalimides and the transamidation of urea, providing the corresponding products in good to excellent isolated yields. The significant highlights of this methodology include efficiency, ease of workup, facile separation, and recyclability of the catalyst; the latter is demonstrated up to 12 cycles. Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Among a range of porous materials such as zeolites, [1] quantum dots (QDs), [2] metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), [3] porous carbon materials, [4] etc. employed for diverse applications, porous organic polymers (POPs) have assumed prominence in recent years [5,6]. Indeed, they constitute a burgeoning class of porous materials with a wide range of applications because of their exceptional physicochemical stabilities and high porosity with tunable pore sizes as well as programmable functionalities; [6–10] the applications of POPs include gas storage, [11] proton conduction, [12] energy storage, [13,14] removal of pollutants, [15,16] sensing, [17] drug delivery, [18,19] and heterogeneous catalysis [8,20–22]. In particular, POPs as heterogeneous catalysts have elicited tremendous interest due to their expansive surface areas and intricate channels, which facilitate easy access of the catalytic sites to the substrates, permitting precise control over the surrounding environment. An incessant quest in the realm of catalysis entails the creation of environmentally friendly and metal-free heterogeneous catalysts that combine the benefits of conventional counterparts, that is, high catalytic activity, reusability and easy separation, precluding drawbacks like catalyst leaching during the progress of reactions [23]. Several metal-free heterogeneous POP catalysts impregnated with diverse catalytic sites such as sulphonic acid, [24] triazine, [25] bipyridine, [26] amidine, [27] imine, [28] thiourea, [29] amide, [29] etc. have been exemplified for their efficient performances. Our research endeavors have been focused on the de novo development of POPs for heterogeneous catalysis [30–34]. While POPs that incorporate acidic sites are known, those functionalized with free carboxylic acids as heterogeneous catalysts are scarce [35–40]. We recently demonstrated the development of a POP with free carboxylic acids, and its application as a heterogeneous catalyst for the synthesis of xanthenes and acridines [32]. An exquisite attribute of POPs is the possibility to create customized environments in their void volumes by a rational design of building blocks and also modulate the environment through postsynthetic modification. In continuation of these studies, we sought to develop POPs that are enriched with carboxy functionalities to explore their catalytic capabilities for organic transformations; carboxylic acids are weaker when compared to sulphonic acids and hence are milder. The present work is concerned with a novel carboxy-functionalized POP, referred to as Carboxy-POP, accessed by Friedel-Crafts polyalkylation followed by hydrolysis. It is shown that the Carboxy-POP catalyzes the transamidation of diverse amides and thioamides with a range of amines. This catalytic process is of particular significance as it permits the formation of amide bonds, a fundamental linkage that is crucial in the synthesis of a myriad of compounds. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis and characterization of Carboxy-POP The synthesis of precursor POP, that is, Ester-POP, was accomplished by FeCl3–mediated Friedel-Crafts polyalkyaltion of diethyl 2,2′',6,6′'-tetramethyl-[1,1′:4′,1′'-terphenyl]-2′,5′-dicarboxylate (TMDC) using 9,10-bis(bromomethyl)anthracene (BBMA). Hydrolysis of the Ester-POP using KOH in EtOH-H2O (2:1) mixture followed by acidification led to the Carboxy-POP, cf. Scheme 1 . The polymeric material was isolated as a black solid, which exhibited insolubility in water and all organic solvents. The monomers TMDC and BBMA, which were utilized to synthesize Carboxy-POP, were prepared following the procedure described in Scheme S1. The Carboxy-POP thus obtained was characterized comprehensively by several techniques to establish the structure shown in Scheme 1. These methods encompassed FT-IR spectroscopy, 13C cross-polarization magic spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (CP/MAS-NMR), elemental analysis, etc. The effectiveness of the cross-linking was established by FT-IR spectral analysis, Fig. 1 (a). The absorption bands at 2928 and 3058 cm−1 are associated with the stretching vibrations of C–H bonds of the methylene groups in the polymeric scaffold, which confirm the polymerization process. The polyakylation leading to polymeric networks is also evident from the absence of peaks at 664 and 1195 cm−1, which correspond to C–Br wagging and C–Br stretching motions, respectively. The absorption bands at 1372, 1452 and 1581 cm−1 are assigned to the stretching absorptions of the aromatic C–C bonds. Additionally, the peak at 1705 cm−1 corresponds to C=O stretch of the carboxylic acid. The IR spectrum of the Carboxy-POP also reveals a broad absorption in the region between 2500–2750 cm−1, corresponding to carboxylic acid O–H stretch. The solid-state 13C NMR studies provide unambiguous information concerning the successful formation of Carboxy-POP. The 13C NMR spectra of both the precursor ester, Ester-POP, and the Carboxy-POP are presented in Fig. 1(b). One may recognize distinct and broad signals at 19.0 and 21.2 ppm, attributed to methyl carbons linked to the benzene rings of Ester-POP and Carboxy-POP, respectively. Additionally, a broad signal near 167 ppm is assigned to the C=O carbon, while a prominent broad peak in the range of 105–150 ppm is ascribed to aromatic carbons. It is noteworthy that the signal at 61.8 ppm in the Ester-POP, corresponding to OCH2, vanishes in the spectrum of the Carboxy-POP upon hydrolysis. This disappearance underscores the formation of Carboxy-POP; the signals marked with asterisks in 13C refer to spinning sidebands [41]. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) profile reveals a broad peak in the 2θ range of 10–40°, pointing to the amorphous nature of Carboxy-POP, [42] cf. Fig. S4. To ascertain its chemical composition, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) SEM, and elemental analyses were carried out (Fig. 2 ). The XPS analysis of the polymeric material reveals the presence of C 1s and O 1s in both Ester-POP as well as Carboxy-POP, Fig. 1a and b. Upon deconvolution of the C 1s spectrum of Ester-POP, three peaks emerge at approximately 284.5, 286, and 289.4 eV, corresponding to carbon atoms in aromatic rings (C–C/C–H), CH2, and COOEt, respectively (Fig. 2c). Likewise, for Carboxy-POP, three peaks are observed at 284.4, 285.6, and 288.1 eV, attributed to the carbon atoms in aromatic rings (C–C/C–H), CH2, and COOH, respectively (Fig. 2e). Similarly, deconvolution of the O 1s spectrum of Ester-POP reveals two peaks at approximately 531.0 and 533.2 eV, corresponding to O=C–O–C and O=C–O–C, respectively. For Carboxy-POP, the O 1s spectrum displays two main peaks at 531.2 and 535.0 eV, which correspond to O=C–OH and O=C–O–H, respectively, cf. Fig. 2 [43,44]. Furthermore, the incorporation of oxygen into the POP was quantified by XPS and SEM-EDX analyses, revealing weight percentages of 14.3 and 28.1 wt%, respectively (Fig. S5). Also, the presence of a homogeneous distribution of carbon and oxygen was confirmed by elemental mapping using SEM and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM), cf. Fig. 3 b. The morphological and nano-structural characteristics of Carboxy-POP were examined by using field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) and HR-TEM techniques. The SEM analyses show that the polymer exhibits a spherical morphology, characterized by a rough surface, with the spheres being interconnected. (Fig. 3a). The average size of the spheres distributed within the polymeric matrices of Carboxy-POP was found to be 645 nm (Fig. S7). The HR-TEM analysis further confirms the aforementioned observations (Fig. 3b). Nitrogen sorption studies were conducted to assess the explicit surface area with architectural rigidity and permanent porosity of the polymers, i.e., Ester-POP and Carboxy-POP. For this purpose, both polymeric materials were subjected to thermal activation at 120 °C under vacuum to remove any trapped solvent/guest molecules. Gas sorption isotherms were subsequently recorded at 77 K and 1 bar. Both Ester-POP as well as Carboxy-POP exhibited a combination of Type I and IV sorption isotherms, revealing their microporous as well as mesoporous characteristics [45]. Additionally, the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas were determined to be 246 and 311 m2 g−1 for Ester-POP and Carboxy-POP, respectively, which point to an increase in the surface area after successful hydrolysis of Ester-POP (Fig. 4 a). Using nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT), the pore size distribution of Carboxy-POP was found to vary in a range of 0.7–17.9 nm with micropores concentrated around 0.7 nm, cf. Fig. S8. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the Carboxy-POP performed under N2 atmosphere in the temperature range of 30–800 °C reveals that the polymer exhibits stability up to 350 °C with retainment of its mass by over 60% beyond 300 °C (Fig. 4b). The initial 5% weight loss observed in the TGA is attributed to the removal of moisture trapped within the POP matrix, presumably by the hydrophilic carboxyl groups present in Carboxy-POP [46]. A substantial weight reduction of approximately 31% is evident in the temperature range of 350 to 550 °C, indicating a decomposition process. Additionally, the derivative thermogravimetry (DTG) profile exhibits a distinctive trough in the range of 300–600 °C, peaking at 410 °C. The trough implies that the weight loss occurs beyond 350 °C, which is attributable to the degradation of carboxylic acid groups (Fig. 4b).[47]. The evaluation of carboxylic acid capacity, expressed in mmol/g, was carried out by acid-base titration technique. Carboxy-POP was initially stirred gently in a 1 M NaCl solution at room temperature for 48 h before the titration process. Subsequently, the protons liberated into the aqueous solution were titrated using a 0.025 M NaOH solution using phenolphthalein as an indicator. Additionally, potentiometric titration was performed using a pH meter (Fig. S9). The number of carboxylic groups within the functionalized polymer was determined experimentally using the following equation: [48]. Ion exchange capacity (amount of CO2H groups in mmol/g) = MNaOH×VNaOH/Wdry, where MNaOH corresponds to molar concentration, VNaOH to the volume (mL) of the aqueous NaOH solution used in the titration, and Wdry refers to the weight of the dried polymer. The acid capacity, determined by acid-base titration using phenolphthalein as an indicator and also by pH potentiometry, was found to be 1.12 mmol/g and 1.10 mmol/g, respectively. 3 Carboxy-POP–mediated heterogeneous catalytic transamidation Based on the literature findings that the occurrence of transamidation is facilitated by hydrogen bonding, [49–53] we envisioned that Carboxy-POP, characterized by its substantial porosity, expansive surface area, and exposed carboxyl groups, could serve as an effective heterogeneous organocatalyst for the transamidation with amines. Our premise was that the carbonyl groups of amides should be expected to be protonated with benzoic acids, which after all is an extreme of the hydrogen bonding, to promote the occurrence of the reactions. Thus, the porous Carboxy-POP was expected, with unhindered mass transport within the pores and catalytic acidic sites in the form of COOH groups that adorn the pores, to facilitate the transamidation reaction of amides with amines. To examine the potential of Carboxy-POP as a catalyst in the transamidation of amides, benzamide (0.50 mmol) and benzylamine (0.55 mmol) were chosen as representative substrates. To begin with, the reaction was conducted in a high-boiling solvent such as p-xylene without any added catalyst. The desired product was obtained only in trace amounts upon heating at 100 °C for 24 h under N2 (Entry 1, Table S2). Subsequently, the introduction of Carboxy-POP (15 mg) into p-xylene and heating at 130 °C for 24 h under an N2 atmosphere led to 45% of the desired product, underscoring the catalytic activity of Carboxy-POP for the desired transformation (Entry 2). Further exploration of the catalyst in different loadings of 20, 25 and 30 mg led to a gradual increase in the yield of the product from 60 to 72 to 82%, respectively (Entries 3–5, Table S2). While a further increase in the catalyst concentration didn’t result in any significant improvement, prolonging the reaction time to 36 h led to the product being isolated in 93% yield (Entry 7). Thus, higher loading of the catalyst in conjunction with a prolonged reaction period led to a near quantitative yield of the product. To investigate the influence of solvents, the model reaction was executed in various solvents such as DMF, DMSO, water, acetonitrile, and toluene, as shown in Table S2 (Entries 10–18). The results showed that no enhancement in the product yield was observed with solvents other than p-xylene. With optimized reaction conditions in hand, we proceeded to explore the generality of this protocol. Keeping benzylamine constant, transamidation of diverse aromatic amides (1b-1f) was investigated. The amides employed included 4-bromobenzenecarboxamide, naphthalene-2-carboxamide, pyridine-3-carboxamide, furan-2-carboxamide, and thiophene-2-carboxamide (Table 1 ). All these amides underwent transamidation under the standard conditions, yielding products in 70–86% (Table 1) Transamidation of benzamide with a variety of arylmethylamines likewise proceeded smoothly and the amides (1 g-1o) were isolated in 81–94% yields. However, the transamidation of benzamide with aromatic amines, namely aniline and p-methoxyaniline, led to the corresponding amides 1p and 1q in rather lower yields, 59 and 63%, respectively. On the other hand, the reactions with primary amines led to very good yields of the transamidated products (76–91%, 1r-1u). The transamidation with a secondary aliphatic amine such as morpholine led to the corresponding amide 1v in only 55% yield. Aliphatic amides, namely, acetamide and phenylacetamide, were found to react smoothly, leading to the products in excellent isolated yields (91–94%, 1w and 1x). Clearly, Carboxy-POP–mediated transamidations work with both electron-deficient and electron-rich benzylamines, aliphatic amines, heteroarylmethyl amines, and aromatic amines yielding the corresponding products in very good to excellent yields. In the same manner, transamidation of benzenethiocarboxamide with diverse amines was investigated. Despite the anticipated difficulty with lower reactivity of thioamides, Carboxy-POP-mediated transamidation proved to be remarkably effective in yielding the desired products when employed with various amines. As can be seen in Table 2 , the reaction works very well with a variety of arylmethylamines and primary amines (2a–2f). While aryl amines such as aniline and p-methoxyaniline were found to produce slightly lower yields (2i and 2j in 58 and 64%, respectively), secondary amines such as morpholine led to a much lower yield of the product (2b, 54%). Otherwise, the versatility of the Carboxy-POP -promoted process is highlighted by the formation of transamidation products in moderate to very good yields with both primary/secondary amines and aryl amines. It is also noteworthy that the transamidation occurs with heteroarylmethyl amines as well, yielding the products (2g and 2h) in impressive yields. Phthalimide, a frequently utilized precursor in the synthesis of pesticides, dyestuffs, medicinal compounds, and various fine chemicals, holds a significant role in organic synthesis. In this context, we wondered if Carboxy-POP could catalyze transimidation. Remarkably, transimidation of phthalimide with a variety of primary amines was found to proceed smoothly, yielding the corresponding N-substituted phthalimides in consistently good-to-excellent yields (79–98%) within 20 h, Table 3 . To broaden the applicability of the protocol, we explored the Carboxy-POP–catalyzed transamidation of ureas with a variety of amines. Gratifyingly, the reaction occurred very well when urea was subjected to transamidation with aromatic as well as aliphatic amines under standard conditions. A variety of differently substituted ureas could be isolated in very good yields, cf. Table 4 . To unambiguously establish the mechanism of transamination/imidation, a few control experiments were performed. First, when the gas liberated in the reaction of benzamide with benzylamine was passed into a saturated aq. CuSO4 solution, a dark blue precipitate corresponding to tetraamminecopper(II) sulfate complex was observed. The latter points to the formation of NH3 as one of the products of the reaction (Eq. 1, Scheme 2 ). Second, the yield of the transamidation product was found to be significantly lowered when the Ester-POP was used instead of Carboxy-POP as the catalyst (Eq. 2), attesting to the importance of COOH groups for the efficient transamidation. Third, secondary and tertiary amides reacted with benzylamine to produce only 5a, establishing the fact that the C–N bond of the amides undergoes cleavage (Eqs. 3 and 4). Based on these results and literature reports on hydrogen bond-mediated transamidation,[49,51–53] the mechanism proposed for transamidation is shown in Scheme 3 . Accordingly, the amide is proposed to be protonated by the Carboxy-POP, leading to a facile attack by the amine. The latter should lead to the formation of the tetrahedral intermediate II as shown. Decomposition of the intermediate II with liberation of NH3 should lead to the transamidation product. Analogous mechanisms should apply to transimidation and transamidation of ureas as well. To assess the partial solubility and leaching of the polymeric material leading to loss of the catalyst, filtration test was performed under standard conditions. The reaction was found not to proceed after filtration of the POP catalyst, attesting to no leaching of the polymer or its constituent molecules into the solution (Fig. S10). At the same time, the reusability of Carboxy-POP in the transamidation of benzamide with benzylamine was examined. The recovery process for the polymeric catalyst was straightforward, which entailed the reaction mixture being diluted with EtOAc and MeOH mixture, and the catalyst filtered. Reactivation of the catalyst involved washing with EtOH, EtOAc, and DCM, followed by drying at 90 °C for 12 h. The structural integrity and morphology of the recycled Carboxy-POP were analyzed through FT-IR, SEM, TEM, and TGA analyses (Fig. S11). The FT-IR data indicated the absence of any changes in IR absorptions after 12 catalytic cycles. Notably, the recovered catalyst maintained its physicochemical stability even after 12 cycles with a slight decrease in its catalytic activity; the latter may be attributed to the closure of some active sites, presumably by entrapment of guest molecules. Furthermore, the morphology of the polymeric material, with no noticeable changes was established by SEM and TEM analyses. The TGA analysis reinforced the high thermal stability of the recycled polymer, Fig. S8. It is noteworthy that several inorganic and organometallic catalysts, some of which can be used as recyclable heterogeneous catalysts, are known for transamidation (Table S3). In contrast to the relatively well-documented transamidation of carboxamides, the reports on transamidation/transimidation of thioamides, phthalimides and ureas are scarce, to the best of our knowledge, particularly under heterogeneous conditions.[49,53–57] A review of the literature indicates that catalytic reactions using Carboxy-POP are remarkable in terms of the temperature at which the reactions are carried out and the number of times the catalyst can be recycled without any loss of catalytic activity. The Carboxy-POP is indeed superior as a catalyst in terms of the reaction conditions that exclude toxic metals, facilitate the synthesis with catalyst recovered by simple filtration, and permit recyclability without any loss of catalytic activity. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have rationally designed and synthesized a novel carboxy-functionalized hypercrosslinked porous organic polymer, Carboxy-POP, by employing twisted organic linkers, namely, diethyl 2,2′’,6,6′’-tetramethyl-[1,1′:4′,1′’-ter-phenyl]-2′,5′-dicarboxylate (TMDC) and 9,10-bis(bromomethyl)anthracene (BBMA), as building blocks and Friedel-Crafts polyalkylation as the reaction for covalent polymerization. The porous polymer is inherently adorned by Brønsted carboxylic acid groups as catalytic sites, as confirmed by acid-base titration analysis (1.12 mmol/g). The utility of Carboxy-POP for heterogeneous acid-catalyzed transamidation/transimidation of diverse carboxamides, thioamides, and imides with various amines is compellingly demonstrated. It is further shown that the POP also works for transamidation of urea as well, leading to differently substituted N,N-diarylureas in very good isolated yields. The catalyst is shown to exhibit excellent recyclability with catalytic efficiency conserved for over twelve cycles without any significant loss in the yields of the products. The exceptional physicochemical stability, which is a general attribute of POPs, efficient catalytic activity and easy synthesis of Carboxy-POP make it an ideal catalytic material for transamidation/transimidation reactions. The metal-free protocol entailing simple separation and recyclability of the catalyst, which conform to the tenets of sustainable synthesis, is highly advantageous over several methods known for the fundamental transamidation/transimidation reaction. 5 Experimental Section 5.1 Synthesis of Ester-POP To a dry two-necked round-bottom flask, diethyl 2,2′',6,6′'-tetramethyl-[1,1′:4′,1′'-terphenyl]-2′,5′-dicarboxylate (TMDC) (0.09 g, 0.20 mmol), 9,10-bis(bromomethyl)anthracene (BBMA) (0.15 g, 0.41 mmol), and dry DCE (30 mL) were added under a N2 atmosphere. Subsequently, anhyd. FeCl3 (0.27 g, 1.67 mmol) was gradually introduced into the flask, and the contents were heated gradually to 45 °C. The reaction was continued at this temperature for 1 h and subsequently heated at reflux for 3 days. At the end of this period, a brown polymeric material that precipitated from the reaction mixture was filtered and washed thoroughly with H2O, MeOH, and DCM. The resulting polymeric material, that is, Ester-POP, was dried under vacuum at 120 °C for 24 h, yielding 0.11 g (83%). 5.2 Preparation of Carboxy-POP The suspension of Ester-POP (0.11 g, 0.17 mmol) contained in a 40 mL mixture of EtOH was treated with a solution of NaOH (0.23 g, 4.06 mmol) in H2O (20 mL). The reaction mixture was heated at 80 °C with stirring for 36 h. After cooling the reaction mixture to rt, it was acidified with 10% HCl. The resulting brown precipitate was filtered, washed thoroughly with excess DMF, H2O, MeOH, and THF. The pure polymeric Carboxy-POP material was obtained by drying under vacuum for 24 h, yielding 0.095 g (93%). 5.3 General reaction procedure for the transamidation A 5.0 mL was charged with carboxamide/phthalimide/urea/thioamide (0.5 mmol), aliphatic/aromatic amine (0.55 mmol, but 1.2 mmol in the case of urea), and p-xylene (0.5 mL). To the resulting suspension, 30 mg of Carboxy-POP was added. The vial was sealed and the reaction mixture was allowed to stir at 120–130 °C until the reaction proceeded to completion. Subsequently, the reaction mixture was cooled and diluted with 10 mL of ethyl acetate. The catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by filtration and washing with methanol (5 mL × 2). The filtrate was stripped off the solvent under vacuum to yield the crude product, which was purified by silica-gel column chromatography using hexane and ethyl acetate as an eluent. 5.4 Microscopic analysis of Carboxy-POP The characterization process involved the deposition of the methanolic suspension of Carboxy-POP onto the surface of a silicon wafer/Cu-coated TEM grid by drop-cast method; the deposition was performed at rt and the cast polymeric materials was dried under a N2 atmosphere. Before deposition, the surfaces of the silicon wafers were subjected to a cleaning procedure involving sonication in acetone for 20 min followed by methanol for an additional 15 min. The wafers were then dried under a stream of N2 gas. The surfaces of the silicon wafers/Cu-coated TEM grids containing Carboxy-POP were examined under ambient conditions using various microscopic techniques, which include SEM, TEM, and XPS. coredata.dc:description: The exceptional attributes of porous organic polymers (POPs) such as high physicochemical stability, intrinsic microporosity, and customised access from simple organic building blocks render them highly suitable as catalytic nanosized reactors. These materials can be engineered in a ‘bottom-up’ fashion by integrating catalytic components into the polymeric structures through facile synthesis based on rationally designed building blocks and judicious selection of the polymerization reactions. Herein, we report that a POP adorned by free carboxylic acid functionalities (Carboxy-POP) on its surface works remarkably as a heterogeneous catalyst for metal-free transamidation, a fundamentally important transformation, of diverse unactivated carboxamides and thiocarboxamides with aliphatic, aromatic and cyclic amines. The protocol is also shown to be applicable for the transimidation of challenging substrates such as phthalimides and the transamidation of urea, providing the corresponding products in good to excellent isolated yields. The significant highlights of this methodology include efficiency, ease of workup, facile separation, and recyclability of the catalyst; the latter is demonstrated up to 12 cycles.
coredata.dc:title: Porous organic polymer with free carboxylic acids (Carboxy-POP) as an expedient heterogeneous catalyst for transamidation/transimidation of multifarious amides, thioamides, imides and urea
